body: can you check if it is possible to use the new operator interface to simplify the loss?  e.g. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/loss_binary_op-inl.h
Oh, I see.

On first glance I think it is could be possible. I will try to work on that soon.
In addition, I would say smooth l1 loss is similar to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/regression_output-inl.h. Is there a plan for the port to new interface of regression output?
The old code will be kept for now. But we would encourage to move to the new one when possible as it is shorter to implement, and be able to expose to both ndarray and symbolic interface
Also out of curiosity: there is no flag in your test suite to run your unit tests on GPU. Was this a conscious choice?
cc @antinucleon

need to change the line to 

``` c++
 dim3 dimGrid((dst.size(1) + (1<<kUintBits)-1) >> kUnitBits);
```

@sbodenstein thanks for reporting this, you mind to open a PR to fix this?

Most of testcase was written for travis test thus not considered gpu when we wrote them. But I do agree that expose a flag to be able to test on gpu is much a better choice
Sure, will do.

Hi Junran, 
I have the same issue as you reported. Have you resolved the problem ? and Can I ask how to resolve it ?

Hey, Mu - maybe you can point me in the right direction.  

As you recommended - I have downloaded imagenet and i'm ready to reproduce the experiment here- http://mxnet-bing.readthedocs.org/en/latest/tutorial/imagenet_full.html

There seems to be some missing documentation links in the **step-by-step tutorial** here - https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/io.html#create-dataset-using-recordio

Should I just use the train_imagenet.py script and point it to the imagenet directory ?  Do I need to use "recordio" files ?

Thanks...
@tqchen Could you update the create new operator document?
@tqchen @piiswrong

We can reduce to 2 inputs and use element-wise multiplication to preserve the merits of inputs `inside_weight` and `outside_weight`. I had no luck finding out how to add a scalar input or a parameter beside two symbol inputs. In detail, I would like to know how to add a float parameter `sigma` to this operator. Could you please point me where to find that out? @tqchen
Is it caused by the fact that the executors haven't been deleted? (Multiple executors may maintain different temporary space?)
the executors should have been deleted automatically in python.

Another problem lies in the composition of loss function.

``` python
data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
inside_weight = mx.sym.Variable('inside_weight')
outside_weight = mx.sym.Variable('outside_weight')
sym = outside_weight * mx.sym.SmoothL1(name='bbox_loss', data=inside_weight * data)
```

Using `executor.backward()` would prompt `Because the last operator is not Loss function, head_gradient is required in calling backward.` Is there a way to resolve this problem?

This sounds like a composite/graph architecture, if I understand correctly.
Does your desired network look something like this?

```
group1 ---> layer1 -----\
group2 ---> layer2 -----|
                        | do something -----> rest of network
group3 ---> layer3 -----|
group4 ---> layer4 -----/
```

If so, [the documentation provided here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/f317c960be2282b0bf7c217fc5163b4211df76ff/docs/packages/python/symbol_in_pictures.md) might be a good starting point, or see [this for an example of more general graph-like architecture](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/5ff545f2345f9b607b81546a168665bd63d02d9f/example/notebooks/composite_symbol.ipynb)

You will probably have to split your data into separate iterators as well, or [use something like SliceChannel](https://mxnet-bing.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.SliceChannel).
Remove the dependency on out_grad in DeclareBackwardDependency will make the layer a loss layer
SliceChannel will work for this

you didn't wait for the forward to finish. thus there will be 1000 execs running in parallel
add my_exec.outputs[0].wait_to_read()

Thank you, so then I can pass it to a fit function to perform the training? I mean something like

```
net = mx.symbol.load_json(path)
model.fit(args, net, iterator)
```

and then pass `net` as the `symbol` parameter in a `mx.model.FeedForward` call?
Thanks all, SliceChannel is what I want.

Use CPU only and check the accuracy.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1228
how to wait for the forward to finish?

try decreasing the learning rate (a lot)?
Thanks piiswrong, it is resolved.
yes
This sounds a good idea to me. a PR is welcomed.

was due to the exact match memory pooling strategy used in mxnet so far. @hotpxl @jermainewang We might want to have a function to manually release all paged memory.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1176 also offers a solution

If we want to make the behavior of the objective a true objective function. What we can do is
- Make sure the forward outputs a `(1,)` scalar of the loss function value
- Backprop as what we did in softmax entropy loss.

Then you can do composition like

``` python
loss = alpha * softmax_cross_entroy(out1, label1) + beta * softmax_cross_entropy(out2, label2)
exec = loss.simple_bind()
head_grad = mx.nd.ones((1,), dev)
# propagate 1 as head gradient back, 
exec.backward([head_grad])
```

In your case, i guess you can likely do 

``` python
data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
inside_weight = mx.sym.Variable('inside_weight')
outside_weight = mx.sym.Variable('outside_weight')
sym = outside_weight * mx.sym.SmoothL1(name='bbox_loss', data=inside_weight * data)
loss = mx.sym.sum(sym)

# propagate 1 as head gradient back, 
head_grad = mx.nd.ones((1,), dev)
exec.backward([head_grad])
```

You might not even have to do that much.
With [`logging.getLogger(<name>)`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.getLogger), for the same value of `name` you're guaranteed to get the same logger object.

So in modules where you want to use logging, you could just have

``` python
...
import logging
...
# A module scoped reference to the logger named "MXNet"
_logger = logging.getLogger('MXNet')

def foo(x, logger=None):
    if logger is None:
        logger = _logger
    ...

# Or alternatively, you could call `getLogger()`
class Bar:
    def __init__(self, logger=None, *args, **kwargs):
        if logger is None:
            self.logger = logging.getLogger('MXNet')
        else:
            self.logger = logger
```

```

rois_data = mx.symbol.Variable(name="rois_data")

relu1_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv1_1, act_type="relu", name="relu1_1")
pool1 = mx.symbol.Pooling(
    data=relu1_1, pool_type="max", kernel=(2, 2), stride=(2,2), name="pool1")
# group 2
conv2_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(
    data=pool1, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=128, name="conv2_1")
relu2_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv2_1, act_type="relu", name="relu2_1")
pool2 = mx.symbol.Pooling(
    data=relu2_1, pool_type="max", kernel=(2, 2), stride=(2,2), name="pool2")
# group 3
conv3_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(
    data=pool2, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=256, name="conv3_1")
relu3_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv3_1, act_type="relu", name="relu3_1")
conv3_2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(
    data=relu3_1, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=256, name="conv3_2")
relu3_2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv3_2, act_type="relu", name="relu3_2")
pool3 = mx.symbol.Pooling(
    data=relu3_2, pool_type="max", kernel=(2, 2), stride=(2,2), name="pool3")
# group 4
conv4_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(
    data=pool3, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=512, name="conv4_1")
relu4_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv4_1, act_type="relu", name="relu4_1")
conv4_2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(
    data=relu4_1, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=512, name="conv4_2")
relu4_2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv4_2, act_type="relu", name="relu4_2")
pool4 = mx.symbol.Pooling(
    data=relu4_2, pool_type="max", kernel=(2, 2), stride=(2,2), name="pool4")
# group 5
conv5_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(
    data=pool4, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=512, name="conv5_1")
relu5_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv5_1, act_type="relu", name="relu5_1")
conv5_2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(
    data=relu5_1, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=512, name="conv5_2")
relu5_2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv5_2, act_type="relu", name="conv1_2")

# roi pooling
roi_5 = mx.sym.ROIPooling(
    data=relu5_2, rois=rois_data, pooled_size=(7, 7), spatial_scale=1/16.0, name='roi_pool5')

# group 6
fc6 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=roi_5, num_hidden=4096, name="fc6")
relu6 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc6, act_type="relu", name="relu6")
drop6 = mx.symbol.Dropout(data=relu6, p=0.5, name="drop6")
# group 7
fc7 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=drop6, num_hidden=4096, name="fc7")
relu7 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc7, act_type="relu", name="relu7")
drop7 = mx.symbol.Dropout(data=relu7, p=0.5, name="drop7")
# output
fc8 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=drop7, num_hidden=num_classes, name="fc8")
softmax = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc8, name='softmax')
```

So I have the following ~very~ rough implementation for training on a generator: 

``` Python
class GeneratorIter(DataIter):
        """"comments removed""""

    def __init__(self, generator, data_shapes={}, label_shapes={}, batch_size=1, max_iterations=100):
        # pylint: disable=W0201

        super(GeneratorIter, self).__init__()

        self.generator = generator
        self.data_shapes = data_shapes
        self.label_shapes = label_shapes
        self.batch_size = batch_size
        self.max_iterations = max_iterations
        self.iterations = 0

    @property
    def provide_data(self):
        """The name and shape of data provided by this iterator"""
        return [(k, tuple([self.batch_size] + list(v))) for k, v in self.data_shapes.items()]

    @property
    def provide_label(self):
        """The name and shape of label provided by this iterator"""
        return [(k, tuple([self.batch_size] + list(v))) for k, v in self.label_shapes.items()]

    def next(self):
        if self.iterations < self.max_iterations:
            data, label = next(self.generator)

            data = [ array(data[l]) for l in self.data_shapes.keys() ]
            label = [ array(label[l]) for l in self.label_shapes.keys() ]

            return DataBatch(data=data, label=label, pad=0, index=None)
        else:
            raise StopIteration
```

Thanks! I believe you need to implement a `reset` function to rewind the iteration to 0 to start another different epoch. Also as I mentioned in a comment above, if you look at bucket-io, you can actually implement your `DataIter` _as a generator_: you can write a for loop with `yield` for example.

Yes you can add a flat layer to flat labels (see the current symbol constructed for char-LSTM for example). There is however one caveat for that: once you start applying operators on the label, during prediction time, if you want to bind an executor without providing label shape (because there is no label), it will fail because the shape inference for the label pipeline will fail. Of course you can always use a slightly different symbol without the whole label pathway. But just to let you know of this potential issue.

Under the hood, MXNet creates two data iterators for the training set and the validation set.
What makes this really weird is that the code that creates both is more or less the same, once it does some type checking/conversion.
They should eventually both reach the same call in `mxnet.model.FeedForward._init_iter`:

``` python
class FeedForward:
    ...
    def _init_iter(self, X, y, is_train):
        ....
        return io.NDArrayIter(X, y, min(X.shape[0], self.numpy_batch_size),
                                      shuffle=is_train, last_batch_handle='roll_over')
```

The default value for `numpy_batch_size` is 128, yet your testing dataset is smaller than that, so perhaps that's causing some sort of shape-mismatch?

`DataIterator` objects are kinda tedious to work with, especially if you're only doing it indirectly. MXNet really wants you to just make all of the inputs into `DataIterator` objects, and so far I've found everything runs more smoothly when I define the data's shape and the batch size explicitly.

In response to the first part: that would seem to be the case. As I understand things, using `DataIterator` for everything is a design decision to increase the overall speed and facilitate distributed training.

As for an example, how about MNIST with a convolutional net? I believe this is from one of the examples but I don't have the link handy right now.

``` python
from sklearn.datasets import fetch_mldata
mnist = fetch_mldata('MNIST original')

# Convert to float and scale between [0,1]
X = X.astype(np.float32)/255

# Reshape into array of  1x28x28 arrays... the 1 corresponds to only gray color channel
X = X.reshape(-1, 1, 28, 28)

# Split the data into training/validation sets
X_train = X[:60000]
X_test = X[60000:]
Y_train = Y[:60000]
Y_test = Y[60000:]

# Create the iterators for the train/test arrays, note same batch size
batch_size = 128
train_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(X_train, Y_train, batch_size=batch_size)
test_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(X_test, Y_test, batch_size=batch_size)
```

We can check that the array looks right, so I didn't make a mistake w/ resizing

``` python
>>> X.shape 
(70000, 1, 28, 28)
```

But we can also check what the batches look like:

``` python
# Get a batch
>>> b = train_iter.next()
# Batches keep track of both data and labels, we want data here
>>> a = b.data[0]
>>> a.shape
(128, 1, 28, 28)
```

You can then perform fitting like:

``` python
# Assuming you've compiled the model/module and you've got the rest of the keyword args in a dict
model.fit(train_iter, eval_data=test_iter, **kwargs)
```

So you can relatively easily define the iterators yourself, and it gives you a bit more control over the training process.
Alternatively, you could try other frameworks like Theano/Keras or TensorFlow, or use those to prototype your network before using MXNet when speed/distributed training becomes more important.

So now they appear to be two commits on the same pull request, #1977

The change I suggested was for `mxnet/python/mxnet/module/base_module.py`, altering line 247:

```
-            outputs = [out[0:out.shape[0]-pad] for out in self.get_outputs()]
+            outputs = [out[0:out.shape[0]-pad].asnumpy() for out in self.get_outputs()]
```

I can attest that it fixed my issues using `predict` and seemed like the easiest change that would ensure similar behavior.
